posts.name: Roger
posts.cooked:
Im coding a command to autoalign, the current logic goes as this: 1)Detect an Apriltag using vision, get its ID. 2) Depending on what AprilTag is detected, the robot sets a setpoint that is fine tuned for the scoring mechanism(depending on if the driver presses the left/right button) that is followed with the press of a button. image 528Ã—588 10.6 KB

image 528Ã—588 10.6 KB

image 528Ã—588 10.6 KB

What Im asking for is feedback on this logic, and if there is a better way to do it, thanks! The command is fairly accurate after a lot of tuning, but finding the setpoints for each of 24 branches is very time consuming haha

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: Are you sure all the setpoints are 0 for tags 18-22? Anyway, you can use a map that maps from tag ID to its setpoints.

posts.name: Roger
posts.cooked: Oh haha obviously not! Im just not done creating the command :b, could you elaborate more on the map implementation? Is that something available already or would I have to create it (Im not really familiar with alignment as its the first time I do it, sorry haha)

posts.name: collin trammell
posts.cooked: Something like the following might be what you are looking for

posts.name: collin trammell
posts.cooked: As far as not having to write out every coordinate, I think if you define the coords for one side, you could likely use something like the following to flip them for the other side.

posts.name: Roger
posts.cooked: I wasnâ€™t familiar with Maps, thanks a lot! It seems like a cleaner way to do it tbh

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: We found a way to be even lazier , without creating a list of field setpoints at all: Define the relative left/right offsets, and then just apply those to the tag of interest.

posts.name: Roger
posts.cooked:
Ohh, interesting! I tested this implementation but the transformed coords were not accurate to the way our robot needs to be aligned haha. I ended up using

to get the relative position, then applying the differences between the x/y as setpoints with great results! Thanks a lot to everyone for the feedback, we got something working that is fairly accurate and fast
